H0.text: Slump leaves behind crescentâ€‘shaped scars on a hillside and may be caused by a layer of slippery, wet clay underneath the rock and soil on the hillside.

H1.text: Creep leaves behind crescent-shaped scars on a hillside and may be caused by a layer of slippery, wet clay underneath the rock and soil on the hillside.

H2.text: Slide leaves behind crescent-shaped scars on a hillside and may be caused by a layer of slippery, wet clay underneath the rock and soil on the hillside.

H3.text: Shearing leaves behind crescent-shaped scars on a hillside and may be caused by a layer of slippery, wet clay underneath the rock and soil on that hillside.

A4.text: Clay expands when wet, then contracts after drying. The expansion portion pushes downhill, then the contraction results in consolidation at the new offset.

A5.text: The presence of water may help the hillside stay put and give it cohesion, but in a very wet environment or during or after a large amount of precipitation the pores between the grains can become saturated with water and cause the ground to slide along the slip plane it creates.
